Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2011 10:36AM Jane1967 wrote: Hi Debra, Sorry to hear that you are now dealing with liver mets. My story is a bit different as I was diagnosed in April 2010 with bile duct cancer because I had extensive liver mets and no evidence of any disease anywhere else in my body. So I started on a regimen of Gemcitabine/Cisplatin (3 weeks on/1 week off). My liver was so enlarged and my abdomen so bloated. Within a month I definitely felt better but still had this large protuding liver. Fast forward to October 2010 and my mammo/breast biopsy confirmed that I have breast cancer and my previous diagnosis was wrong because they never were able to see the cancer in my breast. So my diagnosis changed to breast cancer as my primary with liver and bone mets. Now I'm on Herceptin and Xeloda and feel fantastic. My liver isn't protuding from my abdomen anymore, my liver enzymes are much improved.  I just had a PET scan and everything is stable at the moment. My liver tumors and ascites have decreased.
Posts.Title: Calling All Liver Mets-Need Input dragonfly stitchyphish

Posts.Content: Dec 17, 2011 03:26AM Jane1967 wrote: Thanks to everyone for the great posts! The one coping mechanism that I use a lot is to be in the moment and be grateful for what I have. I know there are people who have it much worse than I. I do let myself grieve for my old life and for the life ahead that I use to plan. I can't plan anymore anything for the future, I do get stuck and only think about the next few weeks or months. There are moments where I think I feel normal and am so grateful to have those. But then reality sinks in and I'm in bed by 7pm because I'm sick or too tired to go on. Those are times where I have to focus on what I was able to do with my husband and children. I tend to not get emotional thinking of myself and my future, only when I think of my children and when they will lose their mother. Then I try to think about what I'm suppose to teach them about life and try to focus on that. Not sure where this quote is from but it goes like this: "Life is not about what happens to you, its about how you chose to live despite it." Another coping mechanism that I realize that I have is that I don't make breast cancer the center of my life. I realized this after I overheard another woman at treatment this week complain about a friend who didn't show up for lunch on her good day and how her disease was the center of her life. Maybe I'm trying to ignore the disease, but I don't want anyone to treat me differently because of it. I decide what I can or can't do.

Posts.Content: Jan 10, 2012 01:56AM Jane1967 wrote: Dear Julie26, I hope your symptoms improve and you have the strength to work through these side effects and feel good again. Decadron can definitely cause mood changes. I am on day 5 in 14 WBR. I can tell you that I hate decadron, it makes me so wired, dry mouth, exhausted, unable to sleep, and so emotional. It's been a little over 1 week since I found out I have brain mets and being on decadron does not help. I feel so depressed and cry at every little thing. Though there's a lot to cry about I'm just not coping with all these side effects well. I count the minutes to the end of the day when I can't get any sleep, Ambien only works for a few hours so even that doesn't help out with the side effects. As for food, I think I've lost some sense of taste as I'll look at food and want to eat it but it just doesn't taste good. I've lost 3 pounds this past week and thats with donuts and pizza and Christmas candy/cookies all over the place.
Posts.Title: Side effects of WBR julie26 china

Posts.Content: Jane1967 wrote: FYI...found this useful online tool, hope this helps TakeThemAMeal.com is a free online tool for coordinating the delivery of meals to someone in need. A meal coordinator is able to create a customized online sign up sheet that makes it easy for friends and family to bring meals. In just a few minutes, phone numbers, driving directions, food allergies, and any other helpful details can be communicated to everyone involved. Dx 4/15/2010, IDC, 1cm, Stage IV, Grade 2, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Jane1967 wrote: I've been stage 4 breast cancer from April 2010. I had a lot of abdominall pain initialy because my liver had so many tumors. After various tratments, in February 2012 after my last set of PET and MRI scans my treatment options disappeared. II've decided paliative care was right for me. I am now being seen by hospice on a weekly bases. I have mets to my liver, bones, brain, and cerebral spinal fluid. I'VE been off chemo fror almost 5 months. I feel good most days but then I hav strong abdminal cramps that want to take over my body. If I eat a sparce diet for the day I am fine, but I;m hungry so I eat like I use to then get into trouble with the ab pains. I take sennakot, oxycontin, prilosec, docusate, and lorazepam to help control the symptoms. Does anyone have anything similar? Solutions? Dx 4/15/2010, IDC, 1cm, Stage IV, Grade 2, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Feb 3, 2011 09:22AM Jane1967 wrote: I too was on Gemzar and after 3 months my platelets went to below 50 and have never recovered. I just had a bone marrow aspirate to see if there's anything going on there that could interfere with platelet production. But for me, my spleen is enlarged and my doc thinks my platelets are stuck in there and I'll need to have that removed. I won't know for at least a week before I get the bone marrow results back.  I had several platelet transfusions with no lasting effect. I also had a weeks worth of daily injections of Neumega (a platelet growth factor), unfortunately the drug does not work very well and it did nothing to boost my platelets. The shots were awful, I felt like I had the worst flu everyday about 2 hours after each injection.  I unfortunately haven't been able to get full dose chemo for months, so we really need to get my platelet problem figured out soon.  I wish you all the best and hope you recover soon!

Posts.Content: Jun 13, 2011 06:46AM Jane1967 wrote: I'm so glad I found this discussion. I haven't bee reading the boards in a while (too busy). I hate decadron and I'm seeing my onc tomorrow to negotiate off of it. I just believe some people are more sensitive than others and I'm one of them. This past week has been so uncomfortable, jitteriness, contstant pacing the floors, headache, eating everything but not really enjoying anything. Thankfully today I feel 100% better and I'm looking forward to the next 2 weeks without decadron!
Posts.Title: Follow up to Decadron Discussions KSkier Jane1967

Posts.Content: Jun 13, 2011 01:40PM Jane1967 wrote: Hi Leisha, I've  only been dealing with this for 1 year but it feels like 10! I too hate being sick not that my side effects are bad. I just finished a round of steroids for my taxotere and that really screws everything up -- I take ambien for sleep, oxycodone for pain, and the antinauseas medications. But then today I feel really good. I'm going to try negotiating with my doc on these meds.Sometimes people are just too sensitive and the doses can be adjusted. Maybe if you spoke to your doctor he can prescribe an antidepressant. I read somewhere that survival was improved in patients who had a more optimistic outlook. Personally I hate taking medications, but with cancer and all the other drugs I wouldn't be surprised that there was depression lurking in there and there is something that can be done for that.  Good luck!
